awd_titl_txt: ENCANTO: Enhancing and Nurturing Careers in Astronomy with New Training Opportunities
awd_abstract_narration:
Enhancing and Nurturing Careers in Astronomy with New Training Opportunities (ENCANTO) is a partnership to increase the number of students from underrepresented groups from Puerto Rico and Central Florida who succeed in astronomy and planetary physics. It will involve an intense research and educational program and provide guidance regarding future graduate programs. The partners are Arecibo Observatory (AO), and three Minority Serving universities - the University of Puerto Rico, the University of Central Florida (UCF) and the Interamerican University of Puerto Rico.  Opportunities provided through ENCANTO will include a wide choice of research and instrumentation projects, and the opportunity to work year-long on a project with a university professor and an AO scientist, exposure to another major research facility through a visit to Green Bank Observatory, and the chance to present at a professional conference in the field.

Students will participate in cutting-edge research using the observing facilities and archival data at AO. Selected senior undergraduates will each choose a research project from a wide range of science topics using the 12-m telescope and AO archival data.  Two of the 12-m telescope projects represent multi-messenger astrophysics: timing bright millisecond pulsars to detect and characterize nHz gravitational waves from supermassive black hole binaries and the primordial stochastic background; and very-long-baseline interferometry studies to image binary active galactic nuclei and predict their evolution and gravitational wave detectability via a pulsar timing array. Other projects include habitability of red-dwarf exoplanets, surveys of Galactic CH and prebiotic molecules, and studies of solar bursts and coronal mass ejection propagation. Instrumentation projects include modeling/simulation of a new solar radar and upgrading the e-Callisto solar spectrograph.  The ENCANTO partners are well-qualified for improving minority access to astronomical research, given their expertise in mentoring students from diverse backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Enhancing and Nurturing Careers in Astronomy with New Training Opportunities (ENCANTO) partnership was established in October 2022 by then faculty members of the Arecibo Observatory (AO), the University of Puerto Rico (UPR), and the University of Central Florida (UCF). Faculty members from UPR campuses at Rio Piedras, Arecibo, Mayaguez, Utuado, and Humacao took part in the program. A key objective of ENCANTO was to provide research training and education for underrepresented undergraduate students in Puerto Rico and at UCF. The program was funded for one year through the NSF PAARE program and ended with participants presenting their research work at the annual winter AAS 243rd meeting in New Orleans in January 2024. One student presented their results at the DSP55 meeting in San Antonio, Texas, in October 2023.

The partnership offered seven collaborative research projects that utilized the Arecibo 12-m telescope and AO archival data. One of the projects included an astronomy instrumentation project to implement spectral kurtosis-based radio frequency interference (RFI) excision. The partnership selected nine students from the University of Puerto Rico, the Universidad Ana G. Mendez, and the University of Central Florida for the program. The research projects were allocated to the students primarily based on their preferences. The students were mentored by the university faculty members during two semesters and spent about 75 hours per semester working on their research projects. In many cases, the mentoring was done virtually as students and their faculty members were located at different institutions.

During the semester, the students and mentors had a physical meeting at AO for 3 days in March 2023. The AO engineering and computing staff provided lectures introducing the students to the computing system at Arecibo, the 12-m telescope, and its receiver and backend. Mentors met the students and interacted with them personally. Additionally, a tour of the Observatory and training to observe with the 12-m telescope was provided to the group. An educational trip was arranged for the students to visit the Green Bank Observatory (GBO) in April 2023, coordinated with Sue Ann Heatherly, Senior Education Officer at GBO.

During June and July 2023, the ENCANTO students participated in an intensive summer research training program at AO. Seven of the nine students attended the program -- one student from UPR had summer classes, and another student from UCF chose to participate in a different research program in Orlando. The summer program began with a course on Radio Astronomy and instrumentation, consisting of 5 lectures. After the course, the students continued to work on their research projects under the mentorship of Arecibo scientists. Some students conducted their research using the 12-m telescope, utilizing over 100 hours of telescope time to collect data. Those students whose projects were not associated with the 12-m telescope also had the opportunity to gain experience by observing with the telescope. Following the data collection, the students analyzed their data and produced the final processed results. Additionally, they prepared an abstract for submission to the AAS 243rd meeting. At the conclusion of the summer internship, they presented their research projects at a formal workshop at AO and composed reports on their projects.

The summer program was combined with the REU program at AO. Most of the REU students were from the mainland of the US, which provided an opportunity for ENCANTO students to interact with mainland students. Additionally, the students attended approximately ten seminars given by faculty members from various US universities and scientists from AO. They also participated in seminars on how to apply for graduate programs, during which several researchers shared their own graduate program experiences. ENCANTO students and Arecibo REU students participated for one day in a three-day workshop on Infrared Astronomy with Space Telescopes at UPR-Rio Piedras (July 27-29, 2023) organized by the Circulo Astrofisico de Puerto Rico.

The AO was closed down in August 2023, but the partnership continued virtually to mentor, plan, and prepare for the final student presentations at a major conference. Five students made poster presentations of their research results at the AAS 243rd meeting in New Orleans (January 2024). Additionally, one student gave an oral presentation at this AAS meeting. A further student made a poster presentation at the DPS 55 meeting in October 2023. Seven conference abstracts were published, five of which used data from the Arecibo 12-m telescope. At least three to five refereed publications are expected from the 12-m telescope data collected during the program.

At least two of the nine ENCANTO students are now in graduate programs, and three are completing their undergraduate programs. The remaining students are interested in/continue to apply for graduate programs while working. We believe that the ENCANTO program has been very impactful in retaining underrepresented undergraduate students.
